titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Henry Graham Dakyns Papers
titlestmt.author: by Leigh Golden and Jennifer Meehan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:16

did.unittitle: Henry Graham Dakyns Papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of correspondence, writings, photographs, financial papers, printed material and other related papers, created and accumulated by Henry Graham Dakyns and the Dakyns family.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This finding aid describes a collection that has been acquired by the library in discrete segments over time. The narrative sections of the finding aid provide information about the content and context of the collection. The Collection Contents section provides a general description and in some instances a box or folder listing of the various acquisitions of the collection. The >Processing Notes section provides information about the way and extent to which the library has processed this collection. The Arrangement section provides information about how material within this collection is organized and tips on how to locate material across various acquisitions.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Andrew G. Dakyns on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2006-2008.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Henry Graham Dakyns Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Henry Graham Dakyns Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, and competing priorities. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization. Material from the October 2007 Acquisition was originally housed in twenty-seven ring binders, with items housed in individual sleeves. During processing, material was removed from ring binders and sleeves, and was rehoused in acid-free folders and boxes. Material was largely maintained in the order in which it was received.

The same goes for material from the November 2008 Acquisition. The original numbering system of the previous custodian is indicated in parenthesis in the each of the folder headings for this acquisition.
This collection includes material formerly classed as Uncat MSS 891, Uncat MSS 974, and Uncat MSS 1142.

Descriptive information is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles were supplied by staff during initial processing. Biographical information is drawn largely from the dealer discription, and is included in the finding aid in order to provide context. Biographical facts have not been verified in all cases.

bioghist.head: Henry Graham Dakyns (1838-1911)
bioghist.p: Henry Graham Dakyns was born on the island of St. Vincent in the West Indies on 1 August 1838. His father, Thomas Henry Dakyns (1803-1874) was a physician, who later left St. Vincent and became an attorney, running several estates. He later moved to England after the decline of the sugar trade in 1845 and was made Sub-Treasurer of the Middle Temple (Inn of Court) in London.

Thomas Dakyns had married his half-cousin, Harriet Dakyns née Dasent (1814-1868) in 1834. They had six sons: John Roche Dakyns (1836-1910), Henry Graham Dakyns (1838-1911), Bury Irwin Dakyns (1842-1918), Charles Stewart Dakyns (b.1844), Thomas Arnold Dakyns (1847-1910) and George Doherty Dakyns (1856-1939).

Henry Graham Dakyns attended Rugby School from 1850 to 1856 and Trinity College, Cambridge from 1857 to 1860. Upon graduation in 1860, Henry Graham Dakyns became the tutor of Alfred, Lord Tennyson's two sons: Hallam Tennyson (1852-1928) and Lionel Tennyson (1854-1886). He held this position at Farringford, Isle of Wight until 1861. In September 1862, he was appointed Assistant Master of Classics at Clifton College, Bristol.

Henry Graham Dakyns married Margaret Cay née Pirie (1846-1908) in 1872. She was the widow of Charles Hope Cay. They had three children, Henry Graham Dakyns (1874-1937), Margaret Frances Dakyns (1877-1960), and Arthur Lindsay Dakyns (1883-1941).

From 1881 until 1883, Henry Graham Dakyns took a sabbatical in Greece to work on his edition of the Complete Works of Xenophon . In December 1889, he retired from Clifton College, moving to Higher Coombe, Haslemere in 1891. He co-edited the Collected Poems of T.E. Brown (1900) with Horatio Brown & W.E. Henley and the Golden Treasury Selected Poems of T.E. Brown (1908) with Horatio Brown. He also contributed the chapter "Tennyson, Clough & the Classics" to Tennyson & his Friends (1911), edited by Hallam, Lord Tennyson, Macmillan & Co. Ltd.
Henry Graham Dakyns died of a heart attack at Haslemere station on 28 June 1911 at the age of 72.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, writings, photographs, financial papers, printed material and other related papers, created and accumulated by Henry Graham Dakyns. Correspondence often contains letters both sent and received by Dakyns, since he made a point of asking for his own letters to be returned in certain cases. Primary correspondents include his immediate and extended family, the Alfred, Lord Tennyson family, with whom he worked, and friends, colleagues, and pupils from Trinity College, Cambridge and Clifton College, Bristol, including John Addington Symonds and Horatio F. Brown, among others. Also found is extensive correspondence between various members of the immediate Dakyns family, including Dakyns, his wife Margaret Elsie Dakyns, his eldest son Henry Graham Dakyns, his daughter Margaret Frances Dakyns, and his youngest son Arthur Lindsay Dakyns.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into four groupings: I. August 2006 Acquisition. II. October 2007 Acquisition. III. November 2008 Acquisition. IV. December 2009 Acquisition.
Material within this collection has been organized by acquisition reflecting the fact that the collection has been acquired in increments over time.

Researchers should note that material within each acquisition overlaps with and/or relates to material found in other acquisitions. For instance, correspondence can be found in all three groupings. In order to locate all relevant material within this collection, researchers will need to consult each acquisition described in the Collection Contents section.
Researchers should also note that similar material can be arranged differently in each acquisition, depending on how the material was organized when it was received by the library.

did.unittitle: August 2006 Acquisition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This portion of the collection contains correspondence between John Addington Symonds and Henry Graham Dakyns, with related correspondence from the Symonds family and writings by John Addington Symonds, including poetry.

October 2007 Acquisition

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material arrived in twenty-seven ring binders, organized according person and, in once instance, according to format. Material was removed from the binders and was largely maintained in the order in which it was received. In the file list below, there is a single entry for each person, even when the material associated with that person was housed in more than one ring binder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This portion of the collection consists of correspondence between Henry Graham Dakyns and his immediate family and extended family, the Alfred, Lord Tennyson family and friends, colleagues and pupils from Trinity College, Cambridge and Clifton College, Bristol.

did.unittitle: Dakyns, Thomas Henry
Dakyns, Harriet

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes various other family correspondence.

scopecontent.p: Includes various correspondence from the decendents of the Dakyns family.

scopecontent.p: Includes Charles Stewart Dakyns correspondence to his niece, Frances, dating from 1917 to 1930.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes George Doherty Dakyns correspondence to Henry Winifred (30 December 1918).

did.unittitle: Dakyns Extended Family

scopecontent.p: Includes the will and estate papers of John Bury Dasent, 1888.

did.unittitle: Hall, Lucy
Alfred, Lord Tennyson Family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Tennyson memorabilia, collected by Henry Graham Dakyns.

did.unittitle: Trinity College, Cambridge

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes letters and memorabilia relating to Henry Graham Dakyns from friends and colleagues at Trinity College, Cambridge, including members of the 'Initial Society' and some of their essays. Also included are letters from Henry Sidgwick, Janet Catherine Symonds, her daughter 'Madge' and Sarah Frances 'Fanny' Alleyne.

did.unittitle: Clifton College, Bristol

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes letters to Henry Graham Dakyns from Headmasters and Staff at Clifton College, Bristol.

did.unittitle: Irwin, Sidney Thomas
Mozley, John Rickards
Pupils at Clifton College, Bristol
Carré, Arthur Augustus
Boyle, Cecil William
Howlett, William F., Jr. and William Howlett Sr.
Moor, Edward Norman Peter
Miscellaneous Letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes letters to Henry Graham Dakyns from a wide variety of friends, colleagues and acquaintances.

did.unittitle: Memorabilia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes family photographs, an 'In Memoriam' for Henry Graham Dakyns, as well as various obituaries, his Rugby School Reports, letters regarding his Cambridge degree, a selection of invoices/receipts dating from 1856, letters in German, a copy of a letter Henry Graham Dakyns wrote to Walt Whitman, and 25 letters from Macmillan & Co. Also includes an 'In Memoriam' and various obituaries regarding Alfred Denis Godly (1856-1925), who was the son-in-law of Henry Graham Dakyns.

did.unittitle: Brown, Horatio Forbes
Family of Margaret Elsie Dakynsnée Pirie
Pirie Family
Pirie Family
November 2008 Acquisition

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into three series: Correspondence, Family Wills and Probate Papers, and Photograph Albums.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This portion of the collections consists of correspondence between various members of the immediate Dakyns family, including Henry Graham Dakyns, his wife Margaret Elsie Dakyns, his eldest son Henry Graham Dakyns, his daughter Margaret Frances Dakyns, and his younger son, Arthur Lindsay Dakyns, and some correspondence with extended family; as well as family photograph albums, material relating to Arthur Lindsay Dakyns, and family wills and probate papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This portion of the collections consists of five books by John Addington Symonds. Each are signed and contain mansucript notes and annotations.

did.unittitle: Symonds, John Addington
New And Old: A Volume Of Verse . Smith, Elder & Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This book contains one full page of pencilled notes at the front entitled "Mss given me by JAS" and a pencilled poem on the final page. Both are in Henry Graham Dakyns' hand.

did.unittitle: Many Moods: A Volume Of Verse . Smith, Elder & Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This book contains on full page of pencilled notes at the front entitled "Mss given me by JAS". It is in Henry Graham Dakyns' hand.

did.unittitle: Renaissance In Italy: The Revival Of Learning . London: Smith, Elder & Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This book contains notes on the final page in John Addington Symond's hand giving literary references.

did.unittitle: Sketches In Italy And Greece . London: Smith, Elder & Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This book contains a small number of pencilled notes at the front, entitled "Mss given me by JAS". It is in Henry Graham Dakyn's hand.

did.unittitle: The Sonnets Of Michael Angelo Buonarroti And Tommaso Campanella . Smith, Elder, & Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
